markdownRemark.html:
I have been a fan and user of the Insomnia REST Client for quite some time. Initially, I was a regular Postman user, but when Postman switched from a Chrome browser extension to a standalone app, their proxy user authentication and support was not great. As such, I could not get Postman to work through the corporate proxy at work.

However, one door closing often leads to another door opening and I am so glad it did. Insomnia is great! I love the UI, I love the name (Finally, a REST client you'll love) and I love that Insomnia has actually taught me a few things I did not know!

cURL

I'll admint, cURL was a little obscure to me. However, ever since discovering that Insomnia allows you to quickly and easily re-create API calls via cURL by pasting the cURL into the 'address bar', I have become a regular user! (Special tip: When viewing the Resquest pane in your dev tools, right click on the request you are interesting and then select Copy as cURL and past it into the Insomnia address bar.)

Combine that with my increased usage of Node.js which has me spending more time in the terminal than ever before and I have started to use cURL to test basic GET commands instead of Insomnia!

Note: This only for basic GET commands, for more complex calls, I still find Insomnia far better

JSON Path

Currently, I am working on a project which has some APIs which returns quite a lot of data. When investigating possible bugs and root causes, I work in Insomnia or transfer browser calls to Insomnia for the following reasons:

  1. Seeing both request and response in one pane far surpasses having to switch between panes in the browser.
  2. Being able to quickly change values and re-submit far surpasses having to redo actions in the browser.
  3. The UI far surpasses what appears in the browser.
  4. Being able to screenshot or share cURLs is far easier in Insomnia than it is from the browser.

And now there is a 5th point to that list: JSON Path!

While, somewhat frustratedly, scrolling up and down through the response pane and minimising/maximising objects and arrays to get a better sense of the data, I noticed the small input bar at the bottom right of the screen. When clicking the little ? icon at the end I discovered this:

Use JSON Path to filter the response body. Here are some examples you might use on a book store API.

  • $.store.books[*].title
  • $.store.books[?(@.price < 10)].title
  • $.store.books[-1:]
  • $.store.books.length

This was just what I was looking for! Using JSON Path makes it so much easier to see get a sense of the overall shape or quality of the data you are getting back than scanning it manually!

It strikes me, that, often times, the best software or technology, not only find a useful place in your workflow, but also teaches or reveals things to you that you were not aware of before. And especially, teaches you things that are really, incredibly useful!
